so nice to roll onto the throttle mid corner without worrying. ﻿

comments.author: sebastian lindstrom

comments.text:
The adjustable panhard rod was installed incorrectly. The adjustment 
side(shorter section  of rod) should mount on the axle end bracket(driver's 
side) and the longer section of rod, which is also stronger section of 
whole panhard rod unit should attach to the body bracket side(due to higher 
forces on that side of chassis as it's a fixed attachment point).﻿
comments.author: 05gtdriver

comments.text: Corvair! Corvair!﻿
comments.author: hulkhatepunybanner

comments.text:
Does your car plow? When you put your car hard into a corner, does it just 
kind of want to go straight instead of turn? Here's a cheap and easy fix, 
you don't even have to get your hands dirty. Take your car to an alignment 
shop and ask them to give your steering the same amount of TOW OUT as it 
would normally have TOW IN. Your front wheels are normally "snowplowing", 
you want to reverse that and have them point outwards instead. This will 
not hurt the car.

The car won't track quite as well in a straight line, but it's barely 
noticeable. When you hit a corner though, my God does it turn in well. If 
you have a car that just plows into corners, this is a really easy cure.

Beware though, having your steering towed out removes some of the safety 
factor built in to your car's handling. It will corner much more easily, 
but if you get too carried away with your cornering speed you'll be dealing 
with 4 wheel drift or oversteer instead of plowing, and that requires some 
skill to manage.﻿

comments.author: smokeystriper

comments.text:
Loving these S197 videos. So many people talk shit about the live axle 
because that's what they've heard, many have never bothered to experience 
what one of these cars is capable of with a couple basic aftermarket parts. 
Thing doesn't even have coilovers or subframe connectors or ultra-sticky 
DOT slicks and it dropped a full second with fresh shocks, a small 
difference in springs, different sway bars and an adjustable panhard bar. 
One second around a short autocross course is a long time...﻿

comments.text:
another way to see if you got bad U joints... or excessive play in the rear 
end... just put it into drive or reverse.... if you hear a PING... 
something isnt right. ﻿
comments.author: kain hall

comments.text:
+L4Z3R37H Yes necessarily, Kain hall's right, listen, you'll know if it's a 
U joint PING, and not any kind of "lash" ping. I know I can tell the 
difference.
comments.author: dan thomas

comments.text:
not necessarily, differentials need backlash in order to function 
correctly. And also, your statement appears that you're talking about 
putting an automatic in drive or reverse. In this case, the "PING" is most 
likely the transmission picking up the lash in the differential. The noise 
is most likely intermittent depending on if the weight of the vehicle is 
resting on the park pin when shifting into gear.
